title: AB 1850
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aiming to educate the public about the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees and government officials. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) issued reports in 1983, including "Personal Justice Denied" and "Personal Justice Denied-Part II, Recommendations." These reports were based on 20 days of hearings with over 750 witnesses, gathering testimony from evacuees, government officials, public figures, and historians. The CWRIC concluded that Executive Order 9066, which led to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, was not justified by military necessity. The decisions that followed were based on race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. Ignorance about Americans of Japanese descent contributed to a policy executed in an atmosphere of fear and anger at Japan, resulting in a grave personal injustice. The decisions that led to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II were influenced by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. Widespread ignorance about Americans of Japanese descent contributed to a policy executed in fear and anger at Japan, resulting in a grave personal injustice. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, declaring it a great day for America. The Congress also declared its support for the act. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during WWII, citing racial prejudice and wartime hysteria as motives. The affected individuals suffered significant damages in education and job training. The Congress apologizes for the grave injustice done to individuals of Japanese ancestry during WWII, acknowledging racial prejudice and wartime hysteria as motives. The excluded individuals suffered significant damages in education and job training, resulting in human suffering for which appropriate compensation has not been made. The Education Code is amended to require eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible aliens to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government, in line with federal immigration laws. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Legislature intends to create a state test for eligible foreign nationals to demonstrate their English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government, aligning with federal immigration laws. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop a test to measure the English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government for eligible foreign nationals, in accordance with federal immigration laws. The Governor, Superintendent, Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, President pro Tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the Assembly will seek approval from the US Immigration and Naturalization Service and Attorney General to use a test for eligible foreign nationals to meet requirements under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent may distribute a test to educational agencies or eligible agencies receiving federal funds to assess the educational needs of foreign nationals applying for legal status. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Test results for eligible foreign nationals shall be confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Upon request, test results may be sent to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Schools and agencies receiving federal funds must administer the test with proper security measures. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to ensure the confidentiality of test results for eligible foreign nationals. Each governing board of a school district must charge nonimmigrant foreign nationals a fee to cover the full costs of instruction for classes in English, citizenship, or elementary subjects, but the fee cannot exceed the actual cost. Nonimmigrant foreign nationals must be charged a fee by school districts for classes in English, citizenship, or elementary subjects to cover full costs of instruction, with the fee not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be determined by the governing board at least 90 days before classes begin. No school district with adult classes can include F-1 visa students in English or citizenship classes for funding purposes. Definitions for "Board of Governors" and "Chancellor" are provided in the Education Code. For this chapter, key terms include "Board of Governors" as the governing body of California Community Colleges, "Chancellor" as the head of the colleges, "Community-based organizations" as approved nonprofits for educational services, "Department" as the State Department of Education, and "Educational outreach activities" as specified activities. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements of the federal Immigration and Nationality Act of 1986 for temporary resident foreign nationals, including adjustment of resident status, sources of assistance, rights and responsibilities, and access to health, employment, and social services. It emphasizes the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident foreign national to service providers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident foreign national to service providers and outlines the rights and responsibilities of foreign nationals and permanent residents. It does not include client counseling or assuming responsibility for the adjustment of resident status. The curr_chunk defines "immigrant" as a non-US citizen eligible for education services in California and "newly legalized person" as someone granted lawful temporary resident status or permanent resident/citizenship status. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "Services provider," "SLIAG," and "Superintendent" in relation to educational services for newly legalized persons. The curr_chunk discusses the rules for determining a person's residence, stating that there can only be one residence and it is where one stays when not elsewhere for work or special purposes. It also mentions that residence can only be changed by both action and intent, and that a woman's residence is not dependent on her husband's. The rules for determining residence state that it cannot be lost until another is gained, can only be changed by both action and intent, and a woman's residence is not derived from her husband's. The residence of an unmarried minor child is where they live with a parent, or the last place of abode if living with neither parent. The residence of an unmarried minor with a living parent cannot be changed by their own actions, appointment of a legal guardian, or relinquishment of parental control. A foreign national, including a minor, can establish their residence unless prohibited by federal law. The residence of an unmarried minor foreign national is derived from their parents. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code is amended. An unmarried minor foreign national's residence is derived from their parents. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code is amended to exempt certain students from paying nonresident tuition in California. To qualify for exemption from nonresident tuition in California, students must meet one of the following criteria: (1) Attend high school in California for three years or earn equivalent credits, (2) Graduate from a California high school, or (3) Enroll in an accredited institution of higher education in California after the fall semester of the 2001-02 academic year. To qualify for exemption from nonresident tuition in California, students must meet one of the following criteria: Graduation from a California high school or equivalent, registration at an accredited institution in California after fall 2001, and for those without lawful immigration status, filing an affidavit with the institution regarding immigration status. In California, students without lawful immigration status can be exempt from nonresident tuition by filing an affidavit with the institution regarding their immigration status. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will establish rules for this exemption. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will establish rules and regulations for implementing student information confidentiality in accordance with Section 69505 of the Education Code. Student information obtained in the implementation of Section 69505 of the Education Code is confidential. Income received as reparation payments for Japanese internment during World War II shall not be considered in determining financial need. Income received as reparation payments for Japanese internment during World War II shall not be considered in determining financial need. The Superintendent of Public Instruction must certify the enactment of the CHANGE Act by January 20, 2017, for Sections 3 to 8 of the act to become operative. The CHANGE Act replaces the term "alien" with "foreign national" in reference to non-citizens in an executive agency of the federal government. The CHANGE Act replaces "alien" with "foreign national" and "illegal alien" with "undocumented foreign national" in reference to individuals in the United States. If the Superintendent of Public Instruction certifies the enactment, Section 2 of the act will become inoperative.
